articleinfo.title: CSBoard Manual V0.4

abstract.para: CSBoard is a simple GUI for gnuchess

articleinfo.releaseinfo: This manual describes version 0 of CSBoard.

legalnotice.title: Feedback
legalnotice.para: To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the CSBoard application or this manual, please, send email to author.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The CSBoard application enables you to play chess with GNU Chess engine. CSBoard provides the following features:

listitem.para: Have following features:
SVG graphics
Native look
Desktop integration

sect2.title: To Start CSBoard
sect2.para: You can start CSBoard in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose GamesCSBoard.
Execute the following command: csboard

sect2.title: When you start CSBoard
sect2.para: When you start CSBoard, the following window is displayed.
The CSBoard window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands available in CSBoard.
Board area displays current position and can be used to making moves
Statusbar shows current state of game.

sect3.title: Make move
sect3.para: To make move you can:

listitem.para: Click on the figure you want to move. It will be surrounded by rectangle, then click on the field you like to move to. If the move is correct, it will be performed and your opponent will start think on his move.
Drag figure to destination field. To cancel drag just put figure back from where you take it.
By pressing on arrow keys move cursor to the field with figure. Press Enter. Then move cursor to the target field and press Enter again.

sect3.para: To castle you should just move king two fields right or left

sect3.title: To start a new game
sect3.para: Choose GameNew.
By start a new game you will completely lose the previous one. So be careful.

sect3.title: To open a Game
sect3.para: To open a Game, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose GameOpen.
In the Load Game dialog, select the file you want to open.
Click Open. CSBoard displays current game position and waiting for you to perform move.

sect3.para: If you try to open a file format that CSBoard does not recognize, probably, nothing will happen.
Also you can open Game passing name of it's file as argument in command line or clicking on it in your File Manager.

sect3.title: To Save a Game
sect3.para: You can save Games to file to open it later:
To save Game, choose GameSave.
Then type the name of file in Save Game dialog, or select existing file
Note that if you'll try to save Game to an existing file, it's contents will be lost and replaced by new game.

sect3.title: To switch side
sect3.para: If you think that your opponent is going to win soon, you can quickly change side and win yourself.

sect3.title: To take hint
sect3.para: You can ask opponent engine about best hint he is seeing in you position. To do it, choose ActionTake Hint.

sect3.title: To look in the book
sect3.para: There is large databases of games, played all over the world. This databases can help you learn correct strategies and investigate current position. To open so named 'Book' choose ActionBook.

You should see the dialog, where possible moves are listed and statistics about it. You can choose the move you like and place Forward or double-click on the line with move. If you can't find any move you like, just press Cancel.

sect3.title: To undo/redo move
sect3.para:
If you don't like the results of your move, you can choose ActionUndo. This will take your opponent move and you move back and you'll be able to make another move. To revert to prevoius state, choose ActionRedo.
Remember, that usually in real life it's impossible to take moves back. So don't use this menu very often, since it could become habitual.

sect3.title: To change playing level
sect3.para: If you feel yourself stronger that your opponent you can adjust it's level with GameLevel. Currently only four levels are possible — Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced and Expert. But real strange of playing depends on many factors like system performance and average load. So don't think that strange of playing is reproducable.

sect3.title: To show last move
sect3.para: Very useful option allows you to easily find your opponent moves. To activate it, use ViewLast move.

sect3.title: To show coordinates
sect3.para: Coordinates are very useful for notation of chess game. To see them, choose ViewCoords.

sect3.title: To highlight possible moves
sect3.para: Newbies are probably will find this option useful. By selecting ViewPossible moves one can take hints on moves that taken figure can do in this position.

sect3.title: To animate moves
sect3.para: To add nice visual animate effect choose ViewAnimate.

sect3.title: To play with another engine
sect3.para: It is possible to play with other engines, like crafty and phalanx. To enable this capability, check GConf key /apps/csboard/engine. Also by using this key you can customize many things, like engine strange. Just pass appropriate options to engine in it's command line. If your engine is not supported by CSBoard it's easy to get it. Look at the sources and write to nshmyrev@yandex.ru if you have any questions.

sect2.title: Let's Play Chess
sect2.para: Chess is a game for two players, one with the "White" pieces and one with the "Black" pieces. At the beginning of the game, the pieces are set up as pictured at right. (See diagrams below to identify pieces.) These hints will help you to remember the proper board setup:

listitem.para: Opposing Kings and Queens go directly opposite each other.
The square in the lower right hand corner is a light one ("light on right").
The White Queen goes on a light square, the Black Queen on a dark square ("Queen on color").

sect2.para: White always moves first, and then the players take turns moving. Only one piece may be moved at each turn (except for "castling," a special move that is explained later). The Knight is the only piece that can jump over other pieces. All other pieces move only along unblocked lines. You may not move a piece to a square already occupied by one of your own pieces. But you can capture an enemy piece that stands on a square where one of your pieces can move. Simply remove the enemy piece from the board and put your own piece in its place.

sect2.title: The Pieces and How They Move

sect3.title: The Queen
sect3.para: The Queen is the most powerful piece. She can move any number of squares in any direction — horizontal, vertical, or diagonal — if her path is not blocked. She can reach any of the squares with dots in this diagram.

sect3.title: The Rook
sect3.para: The Rook is the next most powerful piece. The Rook can move any number of squares vertically or horizontally if its path is not blocked.

sect3.title: The Bishop
sect3.para: The Bishop can move any number of squares diagonally if its path is not blocked. Note that this Bishop starts on a light square and can reach only other light squares. At the beginning of the game, you have one "dark-square" Bishop and one "light-square" Bishop.

sect3.title: The Knight
sect3.para: The Knight's move is special. It hops directly from its old square to its new square. The Knight can jump over other pieces between its old and new squares. Think of the Knight's move as an "L." It moves two squares horizontally or vertically and then makes a right-angle turn for one more square. The Knight always lands on a square opposite in color from its old square.

sect3.title: The King
sect3.para: The King is the most important piece. When he is trapped, his whole army loses. The King can move one square in any direction — for example, to any of the squares with dots in this diagram. (An exception is castling, which is explained later.) The King may never move into check — that is, onto a square attacked by an opponent's piece.

sect3.title: The Pawn
sect3.para: The pawn moves straight ahead (never backward), but it captures diagonally. It moves one square at a time, but on its first move it has the option of moving forward one or two squares. In the diagram, the squares with dots indicate possible destinations for the pawns. The White pawn is on its original square, so it may move ahead either one or two squares. The Black pawn has already moved, so it may move ahead only one square at a time. The squares on which these pawns may capture are indicated by an X.

If a pawn advances all the way to the opposite end of the board, it is immediately "promoted" to another piece, usually a Queen. It may not remain a pawn or become a King. Therefore, it is possible for each player to have more than one Queen or more than two Rooks, Bishops, or Knights on the board at the same time.

sect3.title: Castling
sect3.para: Each player may "castle" only once during a game and when conditions are met. Castling is a special move that lets a player move two pieces at once — the King and one Rook. In castling, the player moves his King two squares to its left or right toward one of his Rooks. At the same time, the Rook involved goes to the square beside the King and toward the center of the board (see illustrations below). In order to castle, neither the King nor the Rook involved may have moved before. Also, the King may not castle out of check, into check, or through check. Further, there may not be pieces of either color between the King and the Rook involved in castling.
Castling is often a very important move because it allows you to place your King in a safe location and also allows the Rook to become more active.
When the move is legal, each player has the choice of castling Kingside or Queenside or not at all, no matter what the other player chooses to do.

sect3.title: En Passant
sect3.para: This French phrase is used for a special pawn capture. It means "in passing," and it occurs when one player moves a pawn two squares forward to try to avoid capture by the opponent's pawn. The capture is made exactly as if the player had moved the pawn only one square forward.

In the diagram, the Black pawn moves up two squares to the square with the dot. On its turn the White pawn may capture the Black one on the square marked with the X. If the White player does not exercise this option immediately — before playing some other move — the Black pawn is safe from "en passant" capture for the rest of the game. But new opportunities may arise for each pawn in similar circumstances.

sect3.title: Promotion
sect3.para: When pawn reaches the last line, it can't move anymore and immediately becomes any figure you choose. This is very useful in the game, since you can promote additional Queen and easily win.

sect2.title: About Check and Checkmate
sect2.para: The main goal of chess is to checkmate your opponent's King. The King is not actually captured and removed from the board like other pieces. But if the King is attacked ("checked") and threatened with capture, it must get out of check immediately. If there is no way to get out of check, the position is a "checkmate," and the side that is checkmated loses.

You may not move into check. For example, moving into a direct line with your opponent's Rook, when if there are no other pieces between the Rook and your King, is not a legal move. Otherwise, the Rook could "capture" the King, which is not allowed.
If you are in check, there are three ways of getting out:

listitem.para: Capturing the attacking piece;
Placing one of your own pieces between the attacker and your King (unless the attacker is a Knight);
Moving the King away from the attack.

sect2.para: If a checked player can do none of these, he is checkmated and loses the game.
If a King is not in check, but that player can make no legal move, the position is called a stalemate and the game is scored as a draw, or tie.

sect1.title: Useful Links
sect1.para: Here you can see some useful links which can help you to learn more about that famous game.

listitem.para: CSBoard http://freshmeat.net/projects/csboard
XBoard http://www.tim-mann.org/xboard.html
EBoard http://eboard.sourcefourge.net
ChessMaster http://chessmaster10.ubi.com/us/
